analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: Manuscript received August 29, 2017; revised November 26, 2017; accepted December 10, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Anomaly detection plays an important role in remotely sensed hyperspectral image (HSI) processing. Recently, compressive sensing technology has been widely used in hyperspectral imaging. However, the reconstruction from compressive HSI and detection are commonly completed independently, which will reduce the processing's efficiency and accuracy. In this paper, we propose a framework for hyperspectral compressive sensing with anomaly detection which reconstruct the HSI and detect the anomalies simultaneously. In the proposed method, the HSI is composed of the background and anomaly parts in the tensor robust principal component analysis model. To characterize the low-dimensional structure of the background, a novel tensor nuclear norm is used to constrain the background tensor. As the anomaly part is formed by a few anomalous spectra, the anomaly part is assumed to be a tuber-wise sparse tensor. In addition, to enhance the separation of the background and anomaly, we minimize the sum of Mahalanobis distance of the background pixels. Experiments on four HSIs demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms several state-of-the-art methods on both reconstruction and anomaly detection accuracies.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: H YPERSPECTRAL imaging sensors record reflected light in hundreds of narrow frequencies covering the visible, near-infrared, and short-wave infrared bands [1]- [4]. A hyperspectral image (HSI) is a 3-D data cube, which contains a series of 2-D spatial images over these continuous spectral bands. The abundant spectral information yields more precise measures and makes it possible to gain insight into the material at each pixel which is a spectrum in HSI [5]- [7]. Since different materials normally reflect electromagnetic energy at different and specific wavelengths, HSI data are suitable for anomaly detection, which has been of great interest in many military and civilian applications for several years [8]- [11]. However, the extremely large volumes of HSI limit its application due to the high cost on imaging, storage, and transmission.

Recently, compressive sensing theory [12] has been successfully applied in image acquisition and compression. A sparse signal can be recovered from a few compressive measurements under certain conditions. It has been proved that natural scenes often contain correlation across adjacent pixels and spectral bands [13], which makes the hyperspectral compressive sensing (HCS) possible.

Conventional approaches commonly implement HSI acquisition, coding, and anomaly detection in separate procedures. This means anomaly detection is done before or after the reconstruction of compressive HSI [14]. Thus, fully sample of HSI with large storage requirement is required which will greatly reduce HSI processing's efficiency. To overcome this limitation, we present a novel HCS scheme for anomaly detection. The image acquisition, decoding, and anomaly detection are completed in a single framework, which is called hyperspectral compressive sensing with anomaly detection (HCSAD). Fig. 1 shows the illustrative example. The hyperspectral imaging system first records the compressive measurements of a scene and transmits these measurements to the processing center for HSI reconstruction and anomaly detection. The advantage of the system is that the restoration and detection processes are conducted simultaneously which will greatly reduce the computational and storage costs in hyperspectral imaging. The goal of HCSAD is to fully reconstruct the original HSI with high fidelity and detect the anomalous pixels in HSI accurately. A good HCSAD can minimize the reconstruction error and maximize detection rate at a low measurement rate. Traditional HSI processing approaches reshape the HSI in a matrix format and treat each spectrum or band as a vector in the matrix. However, the spatial or spectral structure in HSI is broken in this way. On the contrary, the HSI can be naturally represented by a third-order tensor and the robust principal component analysis (RPCA) approach for matrix can be extended to tensor-based HSI representation. In this paper, we propose to use tensor robust principal component analysis (TRPCA) to the task of HCSAD. The original RPCA [15] aims at recovering the low-dimensional structure in highdimensional data polluted by grossly corrupted or outlying observations. In the proposed TRPCA model, the original HSI data are the high-dimensional data, and the low-dimensional data are the background part. As a consequence, the rest of the data is the anomaly part. Since only a small fraction of the pixels belong to anomalies, the anomaly part is a sparse component. Meanwhile, in real world, each pixel in HSI corresponds to one kind of material (pure pixel) or to the mixture of several materials (mixed pixel). The spectrum of a specific material can be represented in a subspace; thus, it is reasonable to assume the background is the lowdimensional data. To characterize the low-dimensional structure, we use a new low-rank tensor definition. Different from the conventional tensor rank definitions (such as canonical polyadic rank, Tucker rank, and their convex relation [16]), the proposed low-rank tensor is based on a new tensor singular value decomposition (t-SVD) and its induced tensor tubal rank and tensor nuclear norm. References [17]- [19] have proved that under certain suitable assumptions, the low-rank and sparse components can be exactly recovered solving a convex optimization program.

In anomaly detection, pixels that have a significantly different spectral signature from the background pixels are defined as spectral anomalies. However, there may be still some anomaly pixels that are hard to be separated from the background as their spectra also lie in the low-dimensional structure. To overcome this shortcoming, we introduce a regularization to force the low-rank component being composed of background pixels only. Inspired by the well-known Reed-Xiaoli (RX) [20] detector, the background follows a multivariate normal distribution; thus, the spectrum in background part has a high probability under the background probability density function. With the generalized likelihood ratio test, the resulting regularization is the sum of the background pixels' Mahalanobis distance and the surrounding neighbors. We design efficient algorithm using alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) to optimize the proposed model. Experiments on synthetic and real HSI demonstrate that the proposed Mahalanobis distance-regularized TRPCA (TRPCA-MD) model achieves high reconstruction and anomaly detection accuracies.

Our contributions can be summarized as four folds. 1) We propose a framework to reconstruct the compressive HSI and detect the anomaly simultaneously in which both the efficiency and accuracy are improved. 2) Based on the new tensor nuclear norm, the HSI is modeled in the TRPCA which fully characterizes the spectral-spatial structure in HSI. 3) We design a Mahalanobis distance regularization to fully separate the background and anomaly. 4) We design an efficient algorithm to solve the proposed model and achieve superior performance over the existing methods in both reconstruction and detection aspects. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II reviews related works. Section III introduces some notations and aspects related to tensors. Several algebraic structures of three-way tensors are defined. In Section IV, we describe our proposed TRPCA-MD model. We present extensive experimental results in Section V and conclude this paper in Section VI.

div.head: II. RELATED WORK
div.p: Different from object detection [21], [22] and scene classification in optical remote sensing images [23]- [27], anomaly detection focuses on distinguishing unusual materials from a typical background with the abundant spectral information in HSI. According to different ways of detection procedure, anomaly detection methods can be classified into two kinds: global methods and local methods. The global methods treat HSI as a whole sample data set, and the background statistical features are extracted from the whole data. The RX detector [20], as the benchmark anomaly detector, is a classical global method. It assumes the background follows a multivariate normal distribution. Derived from the RX detector, many other improved global methods have been proposed [28], [29]. Another kind of global method is based on the low-rank representation [30], [31], which decomposes the HSI into background and anomaly parts. The low-rank and sparse constraints are imposed on the two parts, respectively.

The local methods usually set only one sliding double concentric window to acquire neighborhood background statistic for the pixel under test [32]. Lu et al. [33] proposed joint dictionary learning method and achieved surprised and convinced performance in change detection. Similar to [33], representation-based anomaly detection methods such as sparse-representation-based detector [34] and collaborativerepresentation-based detector [35] use the pixels in the out window region as background dictionary to collaboratively represent the central pixel, while the anomaly pixel cannot be well represented by the background dictionary. To make full use of the local information, local summation anomaly detection method [36] is proposed, which combines the multiple local distributions from neighboring local window with spectral-spatial feature integration. To capture local spectral variations, multiple-window anomaly detection is developed in [37].

The effective way to deal with the reconstruction from compressive HSI is the regularization methods. A proper sparsity prior for HSI is the key point for the reconstruction. Duarte and Baraniuk [38] pointed out HSIs are typically piecewise smooth along the spatial domain and contain very few principal components implying their low-rank structure. Zhang et al. [39] proposed the 3-D structured sparsity of HSI through integrating the spectral structure sparsity and spatial unknown manifold structure. Waters et al. [40] integrated the matrix RPCA in the HCS problem and developed a greedy algorithm to solve the problem. Martín et al. [41] exploited the low-dimensional subspace in hyperspectral vectors and the high correlation in both spatial and spectral domains, which result in minimizing an objective function containing a quadratic data misfit term and the 2-D-total variation (TV) regularization. Golbabaee et al. [42] decomposed the HSI into a linear combination of few sources, each of which has a specific spectral signature, and the spatial abundances mas of these sources are piecewise smooth. Recently, Yang et al. [43] proposed a tensor-based method via sparse tensor and nonlinear compressed sensing. It shows that tensor methods have great potential for HSI processing.

div.head: III. TENSOR NOTATIONS
div.p: In this section, we will introduce some notations and give the basic definitions proposed in [17] and [18].

In this paper, we denote tensors by Euler script letters, e.g., X . A slice of a tensor is a 2-D section defined by all but two indices. A fiber of tensor is a 1-D section defined by fixing all indices but one. For the third-order tensor X ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 , we will use the MATLAB notation X (k, :, :), X (:, k, :), and X (:, :, k) to denote the horizontal, lateral, and frontal slices, and X (:, i, j ), X (i, :, j ), and X (i, j, :) to denote the (i, j )th mode-1, mode-2, and mode-3 fiber. In particular, X (k) represents X (:, :, k). The inner product of x and y in R n 1 is defined as x, y = x T y. The inner product of X and Y in R n 1 ×n 2 is defined as X, Y = Trace(X T Y), where X T is the transpose of X and Trace(•) is the matrix trace. The inner product of X and Y in R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 is defined as i) , Y (i) . The Frobenius norm of a tensor is defined as
div.formula: X , Y = n 3 i=1 X (
div.p: The mode-i unfolding (matricization) of the tensor X is the matrix denoted by X (i) that is obtained by arranging (lexicographically in the indices other than the i th index) the mode-i fibers as the columns of the matrix and denoted by unfold i (X ) = X (i) and X = fold i (X (i) ).

By introducing a commutative operation * between two tubes a, b ∈ R 1×1×n 3 via a * b = a • b, where • denotes the circular convolution between the two vectors, the t-products between two tensors are defined as follows.
Definition Next, we define some related notions of tensor transpose and identity tensor.
div.formula: 1 (t-Product): The t-product Q = X * Y of X ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 and Y ∈ R n 2 ×n 4 ×n 3 is a tensor of size n 1 × n 4 × n 3 where the (i, j )th tube denoted by Q(i, j, :) for i = 1, 2, . . . , n 1 and j = 1, 2, . . . , n 4 of the tensor Q is given by n 2 k=1 X (i, k, :) * Y(k, j, :).
div.p: Definition 2 (Tensor Transpose): Let X be a tensor of size n 1 × n 2 × n 3 , then X T is the n 2 × n 1 × n 3 tensor obtained by transposing each of the frontal slices and then reversing the order of the transposed frontal slices through n 3 .
Definition 3 (Identity Tensor): The identity tensor I ∈ R n 1 ×n 1 ×n 3 whose first frontal slice is the n 1 × n 1 identity matrix, and all other frontal slices are 0.

From [17] and [18], the t-product of X and Y can be computed efficiently by performing the fast Fourier transformation (FFT) along the tube fibers of X and Y to get X and Y, multiplying each pair of frontal slices of X and Y to obtain Q. Then, by taking the inverse FFT along the third mode, the result is obtained.
Definition 4 (Orthogonal Tensor):
div.formula: A tensor G ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 is orthogonal if G T * G = G * G T = I.
div.p: Next, the t-SVD is defined based on t-product.

div.head: Theorem 5 (t-SVD):
div.p: Let A ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 . Then, it can be factored as
div.formula: A = U * S * V T (2)
div.p: where U ∈ R n 1 ×n 1 ×n 3 and V ∈ R n 2 ×n 2 ×n 3 are orthogonal, and S ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 is a rectangular f-diagonal tensor. Fig. 2 illustrates the t-SVD factorization. The t-SVD can be efficiently computed based on the matrix SVDs in the Fourier domain. For details of the computation( see [18]).
This theorem gives an optimal approximation of a tensor measured by the Frobenious norm of difference, as in the following theorem.
Theorem 6: Let the t-SVD of A ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 be given by
div.formula: A = U * S * V T and for k < min(n 1 , n 2 ) define A k = k i=1 U(:, i, :)S(i, i, :)V(:, i, :) T . Then A k = arg min Â∈M A -Â F (3
div.p: where
div.formula: M = {Q = X * Y|X ∈ R n 1 ×k×n 3 , Y ∈ R k×n 2 ×n 3 }.
div.p: To prove Theorem 6, we first define
div.formula: (F n 3 ⊗ I n 1 )circ(MatVec(A)) F * n 3 ⊗ I n 2 = ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ D 1 . . . D n 3 ⎤ ⎥ ⎦(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: MatVec(A) = [A 1 A 2 • • • A n 3 ]
div.p: T , and ⊗ denotes the Kronecker product. F n 3 is a n 3 ×n 3 discrete Fourier transform matrix, and F * n 3 is its conjugate transpose. circ(MatVec(A)) generates all circular shifts out of the fundamental blocks of MatVec(A).
Let n = min(n 1 , n 2 ). Then

Thus, A k = arg min Â∈M A -Â F .
div.p: Then, a measure of tensor complexity: the tensor multi rank is given based on t-SVD.

Definition 7 (Tensor Multi Rank): The multi rank of X ∈ R n 1 ×n 2 ×n 3 is a vector p ∈ R n 3 ×1 with the i th element equal to the rank of the i th frontal slice of X obtained by taking the Fourier transform along the third dimension of the tensor.

Thus, a scalar measure of complexity of a tensor can be obtained by computing the 1 norm of its multi rank. Similar to the matrix case, adequate convex relaxation of the complexity measure is required in real applications.

Theorem 8: The tensor nuclear norm denoted by X * and defined as the sum of the singular values of all frontal slices of X is a norm and is the tightest convex relaxation to 1 norm of the tensor multi rank.
The proof of the theorem can be found in [18]. Let us define blkdiag(X ), a block diagonal matrix, as follows:
where X (k) is the i th frontal slice of
and the 1 norm of the tensor multi rank is equal to rank(blkdiag(X)). Thus, the tightest convex relaxation is the nuclear norm of blkdiag(X ).

div.head: IV. GENERAL FRAMEWORK FOR HCSAD
div.p: In this section, we will present the general framework for the HCSAD task. The mathematical modeling and algorithm designed in HCSAD, i.e., reconstruct HSI background and anomaly from compressive measurements, are the main concerns.

div.head: A. Compressive Operator
div.p: An HSI can be represented as a third-order tensor X ∈ R d H ×d V ×d S , where d H , d V , and d S stand for the rows, columns, and bands of the HSI. Here, we assume an HSI can be decomposed into a background component L and an anomaly component S, i.e., X = L + S.
Compressive operator is an effective encoding of HSI. Here, the compressive measurement y can be obtained by

where y is a vector of length M, and A represents a given compressive operator. In this paper, we use the randomly permuted noiselet operator [44] as the compressive operator as it has low computational cost and easy hardware implementation. Given the above two constraints, it is not possible to recover the background and anomaly component as it is a heavily ill-posed inverse problem. Hence, it is necessary to regularize this problem by discovering the underlying HSI prior knowledge.

div.head: B. TRPCA for Anomaly Detection
div.p: In an HSI, the anomaly pixels have significantly different spectral features from the neighboring pixels. The other pixels can be seen as the background pixels, which are composed of a few ground materials. Each ground material has the corresponding low-dimensional manifold structure. Thus, the background pixels form a low-dimensional component. With the tensor nuclear norm definition and Theorem 8, we can constrain the low-dimensional component using a complexity measure as in [19] and [45] min
div.formula: X ,L,S L * + λS p s.t. X = L + S, y = A(X ) (9
div.p: where p represents a specific norm of the sparse tensor S and λ > 0 is a tradeoff parameter between the two low-rank and sparse terms.

Here, the sparse tensor is assumed to be the anomaly component. The anomaly pixels are separated from the background and stored in the sparse tensor. Since each anomalous pixel has a complete spectrum, the sparse tensor S is tube-wise sparse. Thus, we define
The reason for this definition is that every pixel in HSI can be represented as
div.formula: X (i, j, :) = D Bac a Bac i, j + D Ano a Ano i, j(11)
div.p: where
div.formula: D Bac = [d 1 , d 2 , . . . , d p ] ∈ R d S ×
div.p: p is formed by the background endmembers, and
div.formula: D Ano = [d p+1 , d p+2 , . . . , d q ] ∈ R d S ×q
div.p: is formed by the anomaly endmembers. a Bac i, j ∈ R p and a Ano i, j ∈ R q are the endmember abundances, respectively. Thus, every pixel can be separated into background part and anomaly part. For background pixels, a Ano i, j = 0. Putting all the pixels together, we have
div.formula: X (3) = D Bac A Bac + D Ano A Ano (12
div.p: where
div.formula: A Bac ∈ R p×d H d V and A Ano ∈ R q×d H d V .

div.head: C. Mahalanobis Distance-Regularized TRPCA
div.p: In HCSAD model ( 9), the anomaly pixels should automatically be separated from the background pixels. However, only with the low-rank constraint, the anomalies cannot be fully separated from the background pixels. If the anomalies lie in the subspace that is similar with the background materials, the low-rank constraint will have no effect with these pixels. Then, the anomaly pixels are still contained in the background component. To overcome this limitation, a new regularization is introduced to constrain the background.

The standard anomaly detection algorithm is developed for detecting targets of unknown spectral characteristics against a background clutter with unknown spectral covariance. The classical RX anomaly detector has been successfully applied in many hyperspectral applications [29]. It is based on the assumption that the background statistics can be modeled as a multivariate Gaussian distribution. Given a single pixel X (i, j, :) ∈ R d S as an observation test vector consisting of d S bands, the output of the RX algorithm is given by RX(X (i, j, :)) = (X (i, j, :) -
div.formula: μ b ) T C -1 b (X (i, j, :) - μ b ) (13)
div.p: where μ b is the estimated background clutter sample mean, and C b is the estimated background clutter covariance obtained from the test image. Note that the RX response of a random test pixel is nonnegative. The higher the RX response of the test pixel, the more likely it corresponds to an anomaly.
From (13), we can see that the RX algorithm is simply the square of Mahalanobis distance between the test pixel and the local background mean.

The covariance matrix may be ill conditioned due to the high correlation and high dimensionality of the hyperspectral data. This problem can be addressed by shrink methods for regularizing estimates of a large covariance matrix. Regularization procedures such as PCA-based regularization (discarding the contributions from the eigenvectors with low eigenvalues) or adding a scaled identity matrix (βI) to the background covariance matrix (same with in the ridge regression procedure) [46] have been reported. Hence, the ridgeregularized RX is RX ridge (X (i, j, :)) = (X (i, j, :) -
div.formula: μ b ) T ( C b + βI) -1 (X (i, j, :) - μ b ) (14
div.p: where β is a regularization parameter and I is the identity matrix.

In the ideal situation for TRPCA-based anomaly detection, L should only contain the background pixels. Since the background pixels have low RX responses, every mode-3 fiber in L should have an RX response close to 0. That is to say, sum of all the mode-3 fibers in L should be small. Then, we can rewrite HCSAD model (9) as min
div.formula: X ,L,S ⎡ ⎣ L * + λS p + γ i, j RX ridge (L(i, j, :)) ⎤ ⎦ s.t. X = L + S, y = A(X ) (15
div.p: where γ is a balance parameter. Integrating ( 14) into the introduced regularization, we have
div.formula: i, j RX ridge (L(i, j, :)) = i, j (L(i, j, :) - μ b ) T ( C b + βI) -1 (L(i, j, :) - μ b ) = Trace((L (3) -Re( μ b )) T ( C b + βI) -1 (L (3) -Re( μ b ))) (16
div.p: where Re(
div.formula: μ b ) ∈ R d S ×d H d V is
div.p: In Section IV-D, we will design efficient algorithm to solve the proposed model. Note that this model is convex, so a global minimization can be found and the polynomial-time algorithm, e.g., the standard ADMM [47] can solve the problem. This is superior to the conventional tensor decomposition methods.

div.head: D. Optimization Algorithm
div.p: ADMM is the most widely used solver for RPCA and its related problems. In this paper, we also use the ADMM to solve (17).
First, the TRPCA-MD can be rewritten as the following equivalent form: min
div.formula: X,L,S, C b , μ b ⎡ ⎣ L * + λS p + γ Trace((Z (3) -Re( μ b )) T × ( C b +βI) -1 (Z (3) -Re( μ b ))) ⎤ ⎦ s.t. X = L + S, y = A(X ), Z = L. (18
div.p: The augmented Lagrangian function of problem in ( 18) can be written as

div.head: Lag(X , L, S, Z)
div.formula: = L * + λS p + γ Trace((Z (3) -Re( μ b )) T ( C b + βI) -1 (Z (3) -Re( μ b ))) + W 1 , L + S -X + w 2 , y -A(X ) + W 3 , L -Z + η 2 X -L -S 2 F + y -A(X ) 2 2 + L -Z 2 F (19
div.p: where W 1 , w 2 , and W 3 are Lagrange multipliers, and η is positive penalty scalar. It is difficult to simultaneously optimize all these variables. Therefore, we approximately solve this optimization problem by alternatively minimizing one variable with the other fixed. Suppose that we are in the kth iteration of the optimization of Lag, the induced subproblems are as follows.
1) X Subproblem: Taking the derivatives of ( 19) with respect to X
Thus, optimizing Lag with respect to X can be treated as solving the following linear system:
div.formula: η(I + A * A)X k+1 = η(L k + S k ) + A * (ηy + w 2 ) + W 1 (21
div.p: where A * indicates the adjoint of A. This linear system can be solved by off-the-shelf conjugate gradient techniques. When AA * = I, this linear system has the following closed-form solution:
div.formula: X k+1 = I - A * A 2 B k η (22
div.p: where
div.formula: B k = η(L k + S k ) + A * (ηy + w 2 ) + W 1 .
div.p: 2) L Subproblem: The optimization subproblem of Lag with respect to L can be rewritten as
div.formula: L k+1 = arg min L ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ L * + η L - X k+1 -S k + Z k 2 + W 1 + W 3 2η 2 F ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ . (23
div.p: From Section III, we already have the solution to (23) if we transform it into the Fourier domain, then the tensor nuclear norm of L will be the nuclear norm of blkdiag(L). 3) S Subproblems: The subproblem of Lag with respect to S can be rewritten as
div.formula: S k+1 = arg min S λS 1,1,2 + η 2 S -(X k+1 -L k+1 -W 1 /η) 2 F . (24
div.p: Denote D k = X k+1 -L k+1 -W 1 /η. Then, the closedform solution to ( 24) is given by
div.formula: S k+1 (i, j, :) = max 1 - λ ηD k (i, j, :) F , 0 • D k (i, j, :)(25)
div.p: where i = 1, 2, . . . , n 1 and j = 1, 2, . . . , n 2 . 4) Z Subproblem: Optimizing Lag with respect to Z leads to the following problem:
= arg min
Here, μ b and C b are unknown and should be estimated from the background component. Thus, we use L k+1 to estimate them as follows:
div.formula: μ b = 1 d H d V n 1 i=1 n 2 j =1 L k+1 (i, j, :)(27)
C b = 1 d H d V (L k+1 (3) -Re( μ b ))(L k+1 (3) -Re( μ b )) T . (28
div.p: Subproblem ( 26) can be solved by taking the derivative with respect to Z (3) and set the derivative to 0

and the updating for the penalty scalar is
div.formula: η k+1 = min(ρη k , η max ) (32
div.p: where ρ > 1. The proposed algorithm TRPCA-MD can now be summarized in Algorithm 1.
The reconstructed HSI is X and the anomalies for the pixel (i, j ) is determined by the response of the anomaly component S as follows:
If it is larger than a threshold, then pixel (i, j ) is claimed to be an anomalous pixel.
Algorithm 1 Algorithm for TPRCA-MD Input: the measurement y, parameters λ > 0, γ > 0 Initialize:

while not converged do 1: Update variable X k+1 via Eq. ( 22) 2: Update variable L k+1 via Eq. ( 23 27) and (28) 5: Update variable Z k+1 via Eqs. ( 29) and (30) 6: Update Lagrange multipliers and the related parameters via Eqs. ( 31) and (32) 7: Check the convergence conditions
div.formula: X k+1 -X k F ≤ ε 1 , and L k+1 -L k F ≤ ε 1 , and S k+1 -S k F ≤ ε 1 , and X k+1 -L k+1 -S k+1 F ≤ ε 1 .

div.head: A. Data Sets
div.p: Four data sets are used to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. The first data set is a synthetic data set which was collected by the HyMap airborne hyperspectral imaging sensor [48]. It covered one area of Cooke City, MT, USA, with a spatial size of 200 × 800 and 126 spectral bands spanning the wavelength of 400-2500 nm. The spectral channels in 1320-1410 and 1800-1980 nm are the water absorption bands and have been ignored. A subimage of size 128 × 128 × 64 is cropped as the test image in the middle of the whole scene, as shown in Fig. 3(a). The 64 locations arranged in 8 × 8 grid with different abundances of the specific anomaly spectrum are buried in the background, as shown in Fig. 3(e). The abundance fractions are ranging from 0.2 to 0.9 for different rows, respectively, and remain unchanged for the anomalies in the same row.

Among the three real data sets, two of them are collected by the Airborne Visible/Infrared Imaging Spectrometer (AVIRIS) sensor over San Diego, CA, USA. The image has 186 available bands after removing the water absorption bands and the low SNR bands and we use the first 128 bands in our experiments. There are two kinds of airplanes in the scene that are detected as targets. The first one locates in the up-left corner of the scene and we choose a region of 128 × 128 pixels to form the first experimental data set which is represented as AVIRIS-I. Three airplanes composed of 57 pixels are taken as the anomaly in this scene. Fig. 3(b) and (f) shows the false color image and the ground-truth map of AVIRIS-I, respectively. The second kind of airplane locates in the middle of the whole San Diego scene. A region of 128 × 128 scene that contains 120 target pixels is chosen as the experimental data set, which is represented as AVIRIS-II. The false color image and groundtruth map are shown in Fig. 3(c) and (g), respectively.
The last real data set was acquired by the Hyperion imaging sensor [49]

div.head: B. Comparison Methods
div.p: Since our method has two applications-reconstruction and anomaly detection, both applications need to be compared. For reconstruction, we compare the proposed method with SpaRCS [40] and joint trace/TV norm (JTTV) minimization method [50]. Both methods reshape the HSI into the matrix format to process. Since in anomaly detection, there is no method proposed in HCSAD, we compare our method with the classical anomaly detection methods in which the original HSI is given. The compared methods are global-RX (GRX), RPCA-RX, and low rank and sparse representation (LRASR) [30]. The RPCA-RX applied RX detector on the sparse error component which is obtained using RPCA on the mode-3 unfolding of the original HSI. LRASR also decompose the original HSI into background and sparse error components, but it assumes the background lies in multiple subspaces. So the background component is represented by a dictionary multiplying a coefficient matrix. Besides, to analyze the introduced Mahalanobis distance regularization, we also use (5) as a reconstruction and anomaly detection method, represented by TRPCA.

div.head: C. Evaluation Measures
div.p: The mean peak signal-to-noise (PSNR) and mean spectral angel mapper (SAM) [51] are adopted as the reconstruction evaluation measures. The SAM index is used to measure the spectral similarity by calculating the angle between two spectral vectors of the estimated and reference images. The SAM index at the j th pixel is defined as
div.formula: SAM(x j , x j ) = arccos x T j x j x j 2 x j 2 . (34
div.p: The average SAM value of all pixels in the image is used as the spectral quality for the entire data set. Generally, larger PSNR or small SAM denotes higher reconstruction accuracy. To quantitatively evaluate the detection performance, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves [52] are used to compare with other anomaly detection methods. A better detector would lie nearer the upper leftmost corner and result in a larger area under the curve. Another quantitative index is the area under ROC curve (AUC). A higher AUC value means the detector get a better detection performance. In the experiments, denote δ = 1/(max(d H , d V )d S ) 1/2 , then, we empirically set β = 1e -9, δ = 0.01τ for all data sets, λ = 3δ for AVIRIS-II data set, λ = 4δ for AVIRIS-I and HyMap data sets, and λ = 6δ for Hyperion data set.

1) Reconstruction Performance: In this section, we compress X by the sampling compressive operator A with sampling ratio τ = 0.2, 0.3. Given the compressed data y, we construct HSI by all compared methods. The bar charts of PSNR values in different data sets when the sampling ratios are 0.2 and 0.3 are shown in Fig. 4. The PSNR of TRPCA-MD exceeds other methods. Among the other methods, TRPCA achieves the best reconstruction accuracy, which means the tensor nuclear norm can well characterize the spectral and spatial correlations of HSI. The increase over TRPCA of the proposed method shows that the introduced Mahalanobis distance regularization can further improve the reconstruction accuracy. This is because the low-rank constraint is more appropriate to the background part than the whole HSI. The bar charts of SAM values are given in Fig. 5. The proposed TRPCA-MD gains the smallest SAM value among the other methods. The visual comparison of part reconstruction results is shown in Fig. 6, where the proposed TPRCA-MD yields the approximate results to the original bands. The second row below is the residual images between the reconstructed images and the ground truths. It can be easily found that the proposed method has the least residual. On the contrary, SpaRCS and JTTV have large residual. Fig. 7 shows the recovered spectral curves and the original curves of some background and anomaly pixels in the AVIRIS-II data set. The first row is the background pixel and the second row is the anomaly pixel. It is clear that the recovered curves using It is due to the fact that SpaRCS cannot remove noise in the reconstruction. On the contrary, JTTV removes noise but the result is oversmooth, which is not close to the original image. The reconstructed spectral curves using TRPCA-MD are very close to the original ones since we model the background and anomaly pixels more accurately. Thus, we can conclude that the proposed TRPCA-MD outperforms other methods on the reconstruction accuracy of HSI.

2) Detection Performance: In this section, we compare the detection performance with the mentioned anomaly detection methods. The experimental results are provided via ROC curves and AUC values, as shown in Fig. 8.

For the HyMap data set in Fig. 8(a), we can see the proposed TRPCA-MD gains the highest probability of detection in all false alarm rates and the AUC value in Table I is 0.0509 higher than the second highest detector. This shows the excellent performance of the proposed method. For the AVIRIS-I and AVIRIS-II data sets, LRASR and TRPCA provide higher probability of detection for small false alarm rate, but TRPCA-MD gains the highest otherwise. Besides, from Table I, the proposed method achieves the highest AUC. For the Hyperion data set, the proposed method achieves slight improvements over GRX. But since the AUC value of GRX is already high, the slight improvements can indicate the advantage of our method's detection effect. These detection experiments demonstrate that the proposed TRPCA-MD is effective and accurate in anomaly detection.

3) Parameter Analysis: β and λ play an important role in the proposed method. Since TRPCA model is a special case when β = 0 in TRPCA-MD and the above experiments have As PSNR and SAM measure the reconstruction quality, it can be concluded that the reconstruction quality is robust to λ. As for detection accuracy, the proposed method achieves high AUC value when α ∈ [2,6] and different data sets have different α that achieves the highest AUC. It is worth noting that although α is different among these data sets, there is some criteria behind it. There are 64, 57, 120, and 12 anomaly pixels in HyMap, AVIRIS-I, AVIRIS-II, Hyperion data sets, respectively. Their corresponding best α is 4, 4, 3, and 6. We can find that α should be inversely proportional to the number of anomaly pixels. This is reasonable since λ controls the sparsity of the sparse component. Larger λ means stronger sparsity. If there exists more anomaly pixels to be detected, the sparsity constrain should be weaken which means λ should be relatively small, and vice versa. Thus, we can choose the value of λ according to the number of anomaly pixels. However, we cannot know the real number of anomaly pixels in advance. One solution is to first estimate the number of anomaly pixels and set λ. It is beyond the scope of this paper, and we keep automatic optimal setting of the parameter for future research.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we proposed a novel tensor RPCA method for anomaly detection from compressive HSI. We decompose the original HSI into background and anomaly parts. The t-SVD-based tensor nuclear norm is used to model the spectral-spatial correlation of the background part. Further, to separate the remaining anomaly pixel, a Mahalanobis distance regularization is introduced, which minimizes the sum of Mahalanobis distance between the background pixels and the mean pixel. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real HSIs are conducted to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over the existing state-of-the-art method in both reconstruction and anomaly detection accuracies.

So using S 1,1,2 to characterize the anomaly part is reasonable.

He is currently a Professor and a Doctoral Supervisor with the Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing. His research interests include partial differential equations, mathematical image processing, multiscale analysis, sparse representation, and compressive sensing.
